newsitem.title: USA: US spot LPGs stable in late, quiet trade.
newsitem.headline: US spot LPGs stable in late, quiet trade.

text.p: U.S. liquefied petroleum gas prices were largely stable in quiet trade late on Wednesday with much of the market already wrapped up for March, players said.
"A lot of people have already closed up their positions," said one Houston-based trader. "It's going to be quiet here until next week."
The upcoming Easter holiday will also dampen trade since many players said they plan to take Thursday as well as Friday and possibly Monday off.
In the U.S. Gulf Coast, Mont Belvieu, Texas, spot propane remained between 37.50 cents and 38.00 cents a gallon, with deals done in the range.
Conway, Kansas, in the Midwest, also stayed unchanged.

The butane market was also reported quiet but still hanging on to weaker values following reports that Enterprise signed a contract with Algerian state oil company Sonatrach for two cargoes of butane each month from May through October.
Enterprise would neither confim nor deny the report. But, traders said the company was in the market Wednesday selling propane, perhaps as a possible hedge against against the cargoes.
The butane markets were stable in quiet activity. ((--Laney Salisbury, New York Energy Desk 1212 859-1631))
